metadata.title: Modelling of ME2 devices for hybrid spintronic-CMOS logic circuits
metadata.author: N/A

content.full_text:
Modelling of ME2 devices for hybrid spintronic-CMOS logic circuits
Modelling of ME2 devices for hybrid spintronic-CMOS logic circuits
A Data Management Plan created using DMPonline.be
Creator: 
Creator: 
Emma Van Meirvenne
Affiliation: 
Affiliation: 
KU Leuven (KUL)
Funder: 
Funder: 
Fonds voor Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek - Research Foundation Flanders (FWO)
Template: 
Template: 
FWO DMP (Flemish Standard DMP)
Grant number / URL: 
Grant number / URL: 
1SH4Q24N
ID: 
ID: 
206209
Start date: 
Start date: 
01-11-2023
End date: 
End date: 
31-10-2027
Project abstract:
Project abstract:
We live in a world where everyday objects are smart and each need their appropriate logic circuitry. However, an increasing need for logic circuitry in
a world with limited resources, together with the current energy crisis, forces us to consider energy-saving solutions. One of these solutions is hybrid
spintronic-CMOS logic circuitry, which can possibly outperform conventional CMOS in terms of energy-delay product if and only if they make use of
ultralow-energy (~1-10 aJ) transducers between the magnetic and electric domain. The ME² device is proposed as such transducer to meet those strict
energy requirements. It consists of magnetoelectric (ME) composite materials, containing piezoelectric and magnetostrictive layers that couple via
strain. It encodes information in its magnetization state and uses the ME effect for both its input and output mechanism. However, not much is yet
known about the ME effect at the nanoscale, and, with the aim of energy optimization, a complete understanding of this is crucial to design an
ultralow-energy ME² device. Therefore, in this project, I will identify a full physical framework as well as the working principles of the novel ME²
device via simulations, where I will determine its input and output physics and will propose ME² designs going towards low-voltage performance.
 Achievement of this project enables optimization of the ME² device and paves the path for development of full hybrid spintronic-CMOS circuits.

Last modified: 
11-04-2024

However, an increasing need for logic circuitry in a world with limited resources, together with the current energy crisis, forces us to consider energy-saving solutions. One of these solutions is hybrid spintronic-CMOS logic circuitry, which can possibly outperform conventional CMOS in terms of energy-delay product if and only if they make use of ultralow-energy (~1-10 aJ) transducers between the magnetic and electric domain. The ME² device is proposed as such transducer to meet those strict energy requirements. It consists of magnetoelectric (ME) composite materials, containing piezoelectric and magnetostrictive layers that couple via strain. It encodes information in its magnetization state and uses the ME effect for both its input and output mechanism. However, not much is yet known about the ME effect at the nanoscale, and, with the aim of energy optimization, a complete understanding of this is crucial to design an ultralow-energy ME² device. Therefore, in this project, I will identify a full physical framework as well as the working principles of the novel ME² device via simulations, where I will determine its input and output physics and will propose ME² designs going towards low-voltage performance. Achievement of this project enables optimization of the ME² device and paves the path for development of full hybrid spintronic-CMOS circuits.
